critique: This executive order aims to control direct spending by establishing targets and requiring adjustments if costs exceed those targets. It seems fiscally conservative in its intent to reduce outlays. There's a slight tilt towards executive power as it creates a mechanism for the President to propose spending reductions. It doesn't directly address immigration, national security, or social inclusion. It has a slight impact on economic regulation by aiming to control direct spending programs. It doesn't significantly impact federalism. Given these considerations, here are my initial scores.
